description:
Exactly what you expect from a family owned restaurant. Being the broke college kid that I am, I can actually afford to come here twice a week and sometimes more! The food is simple but very nice. I had one of my TOP 5 best bowls of pho at Golden King. The best part is, during the non busy hours your food comes in like 5 minutes. The Thai Tea is my favorite, never had it before until Golden King and it's my favorite item on the menu. Also their waitress is very nice and does a good job despite often being the only staff member on duty. 

Don't be fooled by it's location and modest appearance! Its good shit.
author: Gabriel K.

description:
The only reason to come here is if 1. You like supporting family businesses, 2. You are just looking for a cheap meal in Chinatown. 
I appreciate their extensive food menu and the pictures of those meals on the menu. However, the quality of the food itself has nothing to appreciate. I had the spicy shrimp with fried rice. When you cook seafood or meat, if you are coating it in a sauce, you still have to season the food with salt and pepper and whatever before you but the sauce on so that the meat itself has some flavor! This is not how food is cooked here so there was not much flavor the shrimp. 
Interestingly enough, their white rice tasted better than their fried rice, ha!
author: Angela L.

description:
Took my SO here to eat after a long day in SF. This is what we ordered.

Pho (for him): Filling, but missing a lot of authentic flavors that Pho is supposed to have. No fish sauce available. He thought it was basic and average. 

Mushroom with Fried Bean Cake + Rice: Bland in flavor. Added sriracha to spice it up. Worked! Sriracha is good on everything. Haha. A tad oily. This dish was pretty average. The portion is large. Definitely filled me up! 

From this experience, the food was average. Service was quick. The food came out fast.
author: Jen N.

description:
Chinatown has three Golden restaurants all within a five-minute walking distance from each other. I mean there is the Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant, Golden King Vietnamese Restaurant and the Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant all close to each other. After trying Golden Flower, I decided to give Golden King a try. It is located on Clay & Walter U so it's in the heart of Chinatown and almost opposite to Golden Star.

At the peak lunch hour on a Saturday the place had only 2 tables full, so it seemed pretty empty. I decided to get the Vietnamese style beef stew noodle soup ($9) to-go. As expected I had to pay in cash as it was cash only. After ordering it was a short 10-minute wait and I was on my way.

I got two containers, a container for the broth and another small Chinese takeout container for the noodles. The broth was really good and the noodles were fine. Overall this was pretty good.

Price-wise it was in-line with what you would pay at other Golden restaurants in the area. I'm going to have to come back and try some stuff of their menu as I liked what I got. A strong 4 stars is how I'd rate this place.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
One thing I noticed that Golden King does differently from other Vietnamese joints is they put toasted garlic bits into some of their pho dishes. This makes the pho quite flavorful!
The restaurant is a half a block from Kearny Street so very close to the Financial District; you don't have to go far to get pho.
author: Joanna T.

description: I walked in and wasn't welcomed. I was already unhappy with their service. My friends and I ordered our food and we waited quite a while before the food came and it just seemed like they were sitting around talking and not working. I minded my own business and then I found a dead cricket floating in my soup. I flag the owner over and she looks at me and said  "oh. Do you want a new bowl?" as if it happens occasionally. So rude. Absolutely unacceptable behavior. Not even an apology or discount on my food. I will never come back again
author: Sarah L.

description:
TL;DR friend from Texas said #13 was the best beef stew he's had in the Bay Area

PLUSES:
+ friendly & fast service
+ yummy broth
+ perfect noods

DELTAS:
- cash only
author: Sophia L.

description: I love this place!! They are very consistent with the quality of the food and the food tastes great. I love the noodles with pork and shrimp. They make fresh lemonade and Vietnamese coffee. The place does get busy during lunch, so be prepared. They only take cash (just like most places in the chinatown area).
author: Olive R.

description:
Quite a no frills decor.  It's near the touristy Grant Avenue, yet isn't filled with many tourists.  Appeared to have a bunch of regulars that seemed to know all the workers.  The pho is ok (hence the 3-stars), but this city has a lot of pho so it's hard to carve out a spot at the top.

Xe Lua: I'm huge fan of beef pho on a rainy day (...or any days for that matter) so even an ok bowl is still a great lunch.  The noodles were nice and firm.  The broth was decent, but I've definitely had better at the pho shops in Little Saigon.  I opted to skip tendon and tripe, since I'm just not into the texture.  The remaining meat was doled out in a generous portion.  The slices of beef were already cooked by the time I got my bowl; I prefer when restaurants make a pile of rare sliced beef so only the portion touching the broth is good.  The beef balls were very tasty.  And the flank was quite hearty.
author: Adam B.

description:
Plenty of tables and decorated with bunch of plants and other Asian decor. Nothing about pho places are notably special and the service is all the same. Their imperial rolls are mediocre. The beef pho wasn't the best I've ever had but I loved that I had the same portion of noodles to my meat, that hardly ever happens! The noodles were stuck together when served which they could've done better at tearing them apart. 

The beef was tender, the tripe wasn't as chewy, and the beef tendon was long pieces. The broth could've been a little more rich. Not sure if it was the pho or the iced Vietnamese coffee I had with it, but almost immediately after I had to go to the bathroom! 

Place is pretty far from the workplace so not sure if i'd make the trek to come here again. I'm sure there are better pho places that are closer by.
author: Jenna T.

description:
Great pho! I came in for the #1 Xe Lua and it was delicious! The meat taste good, a lot of noodles and broth. The broth is literally the best in the city! Maybe I'm over exaggerating or I'm just hungry.. you get the point haha! If you're new to pho, What I am crazy? New to pho? Sheesh just try the #1 and you'll know why I fell in love with their broth & noodles haha! I enjoyed it a lot and will definitely be back!

Pros: 
-Fast
-Friendly
-Excellent broth
-Perfect noodles
-They do Amazon restaurant

Cons (Not really a con but more like a "I forgot to bring cash or I feel like paying with card today"):
-Please accept credit cards soon!
-Cash only!
author: Jonathan Z.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in all of chinatown. It has a home-y feel yet it's clean and feels spacious. There's never a wait (unless it's the lunch rush) yet the food is still great for a low price. Almost all menu items are around or less than $10 and they give large servings. Orders come out quick. Their thai tea is my favorite. The service is as you'd expect from Chinatown restaurants, nothing spectacular but quick.
author: Christine Z.

description: The best Pho in Chinatown! Soup is good. Portion is big. Good for lunch if you can't think of anywhere to eat at.
author: Bella C.

description:
I went to Golden King during my lunch time because I was craving for Pho. After I walked in, I was greeted by this nice and happy lady that was holding her baby. She told me to find a place to sit and told me to look through the menu and see what kind of Pho I wanted to get. 

I ordered the #13 which had a combination beef(s), Vietnamese noodles and broth. Their broth is specutualous and their meats very tender. The best part that I enjoyed most was their broth. Their seasoning is on the spot and my  tongue just loves it! 

Guess who is coming back for brunch? Me!
author: Anthony T.

description: Growing up from a Vietnamese/ Chinese family, i was very skeptical ordering food because it wasn't owned by Vietnamese people. I ordered spring rolls, waited for 15 mins for them. How hard is it to make spring rolls? When I received it, the rice paper was very hard. I can see the poop of the shrimp, which looks unappetizing. Also, two spring rolls were $9, which is kinda pricey, don't you think?  I took a bite out of it and threw it away. This place has gone down and the quality has gone down with it. I will not be coming back.
author: Rachel W.

description: There was a short(perhaps looks like man's hair) stick on my pickle ( carrot ) . Before I left I told the waitress , she insisted that was lemon grass fine piece , (but she mentioned two guys worked downstairs did not get hair cut , does that sound like she thought that looks like someone just got a hair cut and fell in my plate ?) First you said Lemongrass , then you mentioned haircut , but I know Lemongrass fine piece is not BLACK . That hair was black in my plate .....
author: Carrie P.

description:
Finding pho is hard in Chinatown. Especially when there are so many places you could go. But Golden King is a special one for me. Every time I come in, I would get a heart warming welcome. 

I always come in and get the Xe Lua. The Xe Lua has a lot of noodles and broth. The meat is tender and the amount is wonderful. The noodle is smooth and their broth is delicious. 

So what's my rating? 5/5
author: Brenda C.

description: I just wanted some pho I was actually looking for another pho place but I couldn't find it and I came across this place. The family was very attentive. Pho was awesome, I ate the whole thing. And if you've tried pho you know they are large portion. Only accept cash!
author: Cynthia L.

description: Not impressed. There was a kid banging on his drum the whole time we were there. The food came out hot, then went cold pretty quick. About halfway through my meal, I heard a ding from a microwave. The food itself wasn't that bad but it also wasn't that great. Before leaving, I needed to use the restroom but couldn't due to the seat being broken.
author: Jess W.

description:
Wasn't really impressed. Came in on a Saturday afternoon and not a waiter was to be seen so we walked further into the restaurant and stood awkwardly for a few minutes until someone emerged from the back and guided us to a table. 

This place is pretty big with a good amount of tables. The entire restaurant smells like incense but you get used to it after a while. They've got a pretty big menu and everything's decently priced. 

I ordered the pan fried noodles with chicken. The noodles were good, but the ingredients weren't anything special. The chicken tasted weirdly salty but the gravy didn't have much flavor. I probably wouldn't order it again. We also got the spring rolls, which had both pork and shrimp. However, most of it was noodles (not even veggies) and even though they were big I felt they lacked substance. 

Located in the heart of Chinatown, there's a bunch of better options all within walking distance.
author: Alyson A.

description:
Would I travel 500 miles for this restaurant?

YES! This is my first time eating Vietnamese food and I can say that I am addicted to Pho. The house special is extremely savory.

In addition, the service, location, and decor was good. I would definitely come again.
author: Teja V.

description: Horrible quality because everything is frozen. The broth was just plain water. Everything was was so plain. We couldn't finish our bowels because it was so bad! Never coming back to this horrible place!
author: Lexie H.

description: Went there 40 min before closing time (8:30).  We wanted catfish claypot and spicy shrimp fried rice and They said kitchen will close soon, so nothing is available between #48 and #63, which included both items.  Then, we said we will leave because of they don't have our dishes.  Then, they said can you give $1-$2 for restroom use.  All i can say was WTF !!!!
author: Stanley L.

description: i love my vietnamese dives but this was too divey for me. Pretty bad stuff and dirty. not good at all
author: Sebastian E.

description: Absolutely disgusting. DO NOT GO HERE. I will be surprised if I don't wake up with food poisoning tomorrow. The beef was dry, hours old, cold and tasted as if the chef walked all over it moments before served. The fried rice was flavorless. The imperial rolls were SUSPICIOUS AF to say the least. Can't believe this place still runs no wonder why no one was inside.
author: Sharon B.

description: Awesome pho! Quick friendly service and reasonable prices. Great for a quick bite after visiting Chinatown!
author: Lorianna B.

description:
Pho is fine. Never get the Bun bo hue. 

I've come here for the pho every once in a while and it's been fine. It's been a good, spacious meet up spot for hang outs and pho. The only thing to get is the beef pho (#1). Every time that I've been here has been relatively good. 

The experience with the bun bo hue really had me unimpressed with their service and mentality as a restaurant. I had ordered it because it was something new from their menu. When the bowl came out, I saw a lot of spice particles around the edge of the bowl. That was already a bad sign to me because it meant that the broth was a dry mix. It was also a lot of hot oil. Traditionally BBH has spicy oil topped off but this seemed excessive. The worst part was when I stirred up the noodles, the bowl was practically empty. The noodles were all broken. I had asked if that's how it's usually served. The owner was nice and said that I don't have to feel uncomfortable for asking about it. She had asked the cooks at the bottom if they had had more noodles or whatever. For a second, there was confusion and they took a while to come up with more noodles. I was already planning on ordering my usual and sending back what they had given, but they came up with a smaller bowl of just noodles. i had expected them to redo the entire bowl. I ate it because I was hungry, but I was super unhappy. The pig's foot that was in my noodle, was practically inedible because of the hairs and the size. I would have expected better quality since we're so close to the source, Chinatown. They also charged full price, showing me that they didn't value my experience. 

They earn a star for the pho and a star for having a good attitude when I complained. But their BBH was inexcusable and the experience they allowed me, as a customer, to have was very poor.
author: Tina Y.

description:
of the 2 "goldens": vietnamese eateries in Chinatown, their pho was the cheaper by a quaker., noticed bun hui hue(9.25)-quite pricey

spacious but empty when i went in. menu has the usual vietnamese entrees.

eats: pho tai nam(7.1)
-got rare steak, lots of small pieces tendons, sweet broth, no beefy taste, msg aftertaste.
-warm tea served, owner/cashier speaks cantonese.

take outs:
-food average
-cash only
author: Victor G.

description:
Went to a conference in San Francisco and was hungry for some pho. Walking through Chinatown decided to go to golden king. 

There were a couple other people eating when I arrived but it was quite empty. I ordered the house special pho and spring rolls. The pho was ok. The soup seemed a little bland. Spring rolls were good. 

I'm sure there are better places to have pho in San Francisco.
author: Rob F.

description: Okay is this restaurant is horrible. I'll tell you why. First of all, when we walked into the restaurant, there was a three year old boy running around unattended. Secondly, the ambience in restaurant was atrocious and the waitress seemed like a disinterested teenager who wanted to get out of the place. We were seated at a sticky table where we served watered down tea.Then we ordered....It was the worst food I have ever tasted. I ordered spicy chicken curry dish and I couldn't even eat the chicken curry. I just ate the freakin rice. It tasted salty and it has a weird aftertaste. All in all, this was a waste of $10 and I will definitely never come back here.
author: Harika V.

description: my coworker really wanted some noodle soup, so we decided to come here for lunch since most of the other vietnamese restaurants had people waiting outside the restaurant. i ordered a vermicelli bowl with grilled pork, broiled shrimp, and imperial roll. it took them less than 10 minutes to bring out my order. i was really satisfied with the portion size! i really enjoyed the imperial roll and broiled shrimp. the grilled pork was kind of hard to chew too. i started to get full and ended up not finishing my meal. i would definitely come back here for vietnamese food!
author: Sylvia H.

description:
I ordered the Chicken vermicelli which was good.  I would have liked more vegetables and hot peppers to jazz it up.  

Portion size is good.
author: Dennis W.

description: Staff was not very polite. They had a day care set up right when you walk in. The food was not good. Flavors were very bland. Very disappointed.
author: Addie P.

description:
We stopped in here for lunch and I had the Crispy Noodle (#49) and my wife had a pho. Both were excellent.

The place was fairly clean, though the bathrooms were questionable.

This place appears to be family run and that is always enjoyable to see.
author: John D.

description:
Pho is in my top 5 favorite foods.

Golden King is walking distance from work with yummy, comforting, consistent food.

It gets PACKED 12-12:30, but acknowledgment is prompt.

#18 with egg noodles is my go to ( i know it's not traditional pho :P) but the beef pho is consistent. Not the very best I've had but satisfies my weekly cravings.

Always order imperial rolls. Crispy and hot mmmmm! Can add 2 to each order for $2. Best off ordering the full portion for the table.

The employees remember regulars and their orders. We heart you Golden King!
author: Heather H.

description: This is my Vietnamese restaurant in SF Chinatown. Great beef pho and only costs less than $8. Imperial rolls great too. Nice ambiance and lots of space.
author: FJ D.

description: Vegetarian noodle bowl loaded with vegetables and shrimp fried rice. Large portions. Second time here!! Fast, fresh and delicious!! Cash only.
author: Lisa G.

description:
I make the 3/4th mile 10 min trek from Soma here 10 blocks walking for Pho Mondays once or twice a month.

$7 large bowl of delish beef pho with all the fixings. Yes! Great cuts of meet, delish broth. Really good for the area and quality.

Also, and hugely important, it has 2 big big rooms, about 2x the size of normal pho restaurants, meaning you'll get a seat and won't have to wait in line like any other popular pho spot around downtown SF.

FYI Cash only.
author: Chuck N.

description:
This place is solid!

We got the Five Spice Chicken with vermicelli and the Seafood Chow Fun. Both were around $8-9 and came in big portions. The chicken was tender and flavorful and with the cold noodles and refreshing vegetables made a really great dish for a hot day. The seafood chow fun wasn't too salty and had a variety of seafood. We also got the 3 color bean drink, which is sweet and fun. We left stuffed and satisfied.
author: Sherry L.

description:
This place is terrible relative to the other Vietnamese options in its area. The food was bland, skimpy (less meat, mostly rice/noodles) and just not great on the flavor scale. Also, there is nothing special on the menu or a "star" dish. 

Came here for lunch twice because Golden Star's line was too long, was dissapointed both times. 

No wonder it doesn't draw a crowd like its neighboring restuarants.
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description: Gave it three stars. Bit of a let down here. Food was a pleasant change. Five slice chicken was above average. Rice was excellent. Shrimp dish was splendid.  Neither of us had ever tried pho and we gave it s shot. It's very different but good. Step out of your comfort zone and give this place a shot.
author: Justin T.

description: CASH ONLY! Came for lunch on a work day, slow service and grilled meats were cold. Prices were high considering the food wasn't great. Not coming back again.
author: Grace L.

description: Great service and authentic Vietnamese food (my mother in law is Vietnamese, so I kind of know the taste)
author: Matteo T.

description:
9/4/13 Lunch

3.5*  Rumors have it that this place and Golden Star near Plymouth Garage are sister restaurants (different branches of family). So with Golden Star is packed to the gunwales with five different parties sharing a table, I came to the quiet oasis of Golden King.

Usually I get pho but on a very balmy day and my back as already semi-soaked, I opted for the dry vermicelli. The BBQ Pork & Imperial Roll bún  ($7.50) was standard fare. Unlike many other restaurants, Golden King gives you more meat than rolls in the combo. Slices of pork are marinated and tasty. Asian preparation of meat is all about marinade. Golden King pork is not an exception. I could taste an aromatic mix of shallots, garlic, lemongrass, honey, fish sauce, and sesame oil that has permeated the meat.  The rolls, however, are a bit disappointing. The meat stuffing has too much of a fish sauce taste. They are also smaller.

Overall it's not a bad place for quick lunch. It's actually one of the better places in the area for pho and bún.
author: Matt Y.

description:
I loved the pho bo kho here (beef stew pho). It's a red, thicker, spicier broth with pieces of tender tender beef & fat in it. The bowl is HUGE! It's good to split with one other person. This particular dish is pricier than other pho's/pho places, but it's definitely worth it for the amount you get. I'm not going to lie - it is super oily, fatty, & definitely has MSG in there, but that's what makes it tastes SO GOOD. I was so bloated & dehydrated after, but that will not stop me from coming back for more!

The restaurant is also cleaner than other places, considering it's in Chinatown. And since it is in this location, parking is obviously horendous! I suggest catching public trans if you can. There's only metered parking nearby, 1 hr max.
author: Alysha K.

description: I recently came here for dinner with a couple of old friends and ordered the #43. It's been 8 years since I first wrote a review and the food still tastes the same after all these years. If you want to find a consistent Vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown, I suggest you come here. You won't be disappointed!
author: Jenn W.

description: What happened to this place?! Used to come here all the time back in middle school. Went here last week and left so disappointed. The noodles were very soggy and the soup was bland.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Came here by accident actually (was actually looking for Golden Star across the street) on a mission to satisfy my craving for pho. I was pretty disappointed with my experience here. First of all, the restaurant was not clean. Literally every other table of the restaurant had bowls and food from previous customers. These bowls were left unclean the entire time I was there... I thought at some point that the servers would clear the tables, but it never happened. Next, the food was mediocre at best. The portions were large and there was a fair amount of meat/tendons in the bowl. However, the broth (the most important part) was not flavourful at all and did not taste like beef. Also, the thai basil, bean sprouts and lime were only brought out when we mentioned it. Not impressed. 

Prices are good but there's gotta be better pho out there in the city.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Chinatown's Clay Street has two good Vietnamese restaurants.(Golden Star and here, Golden King). Usually these two places are busy during noon time, but really quiet in the early evening. You can't go wrong with any of the two places, which is several feet away from each other. 

I took four of my "massive" co-workers here for an early dinner. 

Co-workers had various rice plates and soups respectively. I had #43 for $7.25, which is the Grilled Pork with Sliced Imperial Rolls and soft Vermicelli Noodles. I may not know the name of many Vietnamese dishes, but I'm sure many of you know what I'm referring too. And every item in the bowl is cooked fresh with fresh Bean Sprouts, Sliced Daikon and Carrots. The dipping sauce adds a spicy kick to my bowl of noodles. 

My co-workers loved all their foods.

One of my co-worker had the 3-bean multi-color drink on ice. And for an ex-lineman in college, he thought the drink was refreshing. 

Another one of my colleagues just got a raise and paid all our meals in cash, in which the restaurant only accepts. 

The waitresses are nice and accommodated our needs. I'm definitely coming back here for dinner.
author: Matt G.

description: really good pho. However the restaurant cashier section should be more clean, and there are kids from owners apparently playing around. the pho is incredibly good and cheap, I only go  there for Pho, don't know about the rest of plates.
author: Diana M.

description:
For the longest time I had no idea that SF actually had some good Pho. The line at Golden Star seems enormously long every time I come to Chinatown for lunch, so I've decided the last two times to head to this place across the street.

It hasn't been a bad decision. For $7.65 flat I got a Pho #1 special, not really too bad these days.

The broth has decently good flavor. Unlike some places in the Peninsula I been to like Pho Saigon in SSF, I'm not chugging cups of water afterwards (sodium and msg content is balanced). There's a good amount of noodles and meat in the large. It definitely hits the spot and gets me full.

Just the fact you don't get a MSG/sodium lunch time FOOD COMA makes this place FOUR stars in my book.

Yea, the service is pretty horrible here. It's like the waitress is intentionally having an IQ of 55.

The first time I went here, I asked for the bill and handed them a $20. 10 minutes later, I didn't get any change. Obviously I'm not leaving a $12 tip for a $8 bowl of Pho, get real. They even asked me "how much money" I gave them because they forgot. Wow.

You think that would chase me away, but I came back the very next week. This is my new "go to" spot for lunch Pho. I could definitely see myself coming back to this place if I happened to be in the area (and Golden Star was crowded).

Great SF Pho!
author: Doug R.

description:
So I've decided I like Pho.  And honestly it's all good.  Filling and delicious.  And their's met the mark.  I have to say the rare steak pieces were better than some places.  I didn't love the meatballs, but my fiancee did, so I guess they were good too.  The rest... spot on.  

There was no one here when we got there (it was a tuesday), and Pho is usually fast, but it certainly was quick today!

And you know what else is so great about Pho? It's so cheap! I was so full! It's cash only, but when your entire bill comes to $13.80, that really shouldn't be a problem
author: Sarah C.

description:
I stopped by with a coworker while in SF on business based on Yelp reviews.  I wouldn't have fought the traffic if it wasn't his night to pick but I'm glad it was.

The menu has a lot to offer and it was tough to make a choice.  We split the Shrimp & Pork Rolls and I had Lemon Grass Chicken over Noodles.  He had the Pho Beef House Special.  The food was fresh, wholesome and authentic.

The atmosphere is very minimal (diner like) but that's never a big factor for me.  The service was fantastic and the prices very reasonable.

I would definitely go back to try something else.
author: George F.

description:
DECENT.
(3 stars)

When did Pho Gai have chopped intestine as chicken meat?

- PHO, ok
- PRICES, ok
- SERVICE, good
- AMBIANCE, roomy

After the run club, some friends from the club and I decided to get something to eat afterwards. We really had no intention to come here after trying to figure out if we want ramen, Singapore food, chinese, vietnamese.... we ended up settling for this place because it was the closest Pho spot.

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS.

PHO GAI (+$7) - Asked for rice noodles and when it came out it looked like decent pho. Broth was good, had better and had worst at other places. My noodles were clinging together and didnt break loose as I'd like them too. I had to switft thru my chicken meat to make sure "is this chicken???" to find out that half of it was chicken meat and half of it was likely chopped chicken intestine?!!!! I'll just eat the noodles and call it even from there. HA!

COMBINATION #1 (recommended by owner) - One of my friends ordered this and THERE WAS ALOT OF MEAT. Just had to put that in my review because you don't see pho bowls with that much meat in it.

Will I be back? I'd rather walk across the street and Golden Star or a block and a half down to another Pho place on Washington street.

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
As Golden Star, my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in town was closed, I choose this one to get some decent pho. 

Soup was good aside from the hair that was in my bowl. Anyway, the personell reacted appropriate and didn't charge me, which showed me that they do care about their quality. 

There are definitely worse places to go to in Chinatown.
author: Rudi B.

description:
Mm... pho with a lot of Chinese influences; what else would you expect eating at a Vietnamese noodle shop located in SF Chinatown?  Regardless, the pho here was actually not too bad, but I've had better.

My friends and I showed up around noon and snagged us a table.  It got REALLY busy between 12 and 1, and there were many large crowds inside.  Luckily the restaurant is pretty big so that wasn't a whole lot of trouble getting a table.  Once seated, the nice servers gave us tea, which was nice to have instead of just iced water.

My friend got the imperial rolls and I got their usual combo pho (#1) that I aim for at pho places.  The imperial rolls were delicious.  The plate contains six for $6, a decent price for some great Vietnamese egg rolls.  The pho I had wasn't too bad either.  There was a generous helping of meat, but I'd say I have had better broths.  My friends also got an order of Vietnamese Iced Coffee, which turned out too bitter so they asked for some more condensed milk... and they delivered.
author: Andy N.

description: Perfect lunch place with good beef pho for under 8$. The iced Vietnamese coffee was really good for getting the energy for a sunny day in sf. Friendly staff :)
author: Per E.

description:
This is my go-to lunch spot and I will always order spicy beef pho aka no.11. I don't understand why but the broth is like cocaine to me. Its spiciness added with the extra fragrance of Vietnamese herbs makes this usual beef pho addicting!!!

Nevertheless, waiter/waitress may not be as patient as other local financial district restaurant during busy hours, but its chinatown!!! As long as there is good food and quick service, I am satisfied!
author: Mau Kwong Marco C.

description:
14.12.19     First Visit
                   Simple review ... what is there to say

Basically a good Vietnamese joint.
Located in the Chinatown area.
Across from Plymouth Square

Basically a "BREAD and BUTTER" Vietnamese.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
Best place for Pho in Chinatown!

Been coming here for years, about half a decade now, and this place is still crackin'. They give you large portion size and the beef broth actually has taste! Also, it's pretty inexpensive (your in freakin' chinatown afterall) and fills you up pretty good. 

However, I do believe that a pho restaurant is the best place to operate a family daycare. (The owner sometimes will have her baby in her hand and the son will be in the back table doing homework or watching the Disney channel. You'll see)
author: Albert L.

description: The phō wasn't that extraordinary really. Iced Vietnamese coffe was really good and the prices were cheap. Under 8 $ for phō. I had the beef phō, and the beef wasn't really that good.
author: Alexander R.

description:
Have not people tried any better soup anywhere?
My husband and I tried the seafood and beef pho soups. Very bland unless you add the spicy sauce you can get from the grocery store. Seafood soup does not taste like seafood at all. What is in there?

It is not appetizing to see the raw beef in my soup top. I assumed the beef would have been cooked in the soup!

Food serving service is extremely bad. Only two servers speak english. The rest of the waitress and waiters only yell at each other in vietnamese. There is an old lady who is a busboy, drops things on the floor, pick them up and serve. EWWWW

I did not know they only accept cash. Why do I have to go and pay extra cash for withdrawing cash from ATM where the service company should have the card reader? 

Sanitation is horrible. Does this place have special permit to run this restaurant or is it ok because it is in China town? Why running unsafe and dirty place is OK??? Just go in and see it yourself. 

Initially I was looking for the Golden Start Vietnamese restaurant and accidentally went to this one since it was on the way. BIG MISTAKE!
author: Julie S.

description: finally went again.  still enjoyed, but I think after much reflection and many reviews since my first, they deserve a 4.  Had the Pork over Vermicelli and not a huge amount of meat, but it was enough and so far, don't feel that MSG-like discomfort.  Toothpicks were good.
author: Marc S.

description: Pretty standard Beef Noodle Pho but the broth is some of the best I've had. Really enjoyed it!
author: Sarah S.

description: First of all, I never expect much quality when eating in a restaurant in Chinatown. However, this place is just plain scary. I ordered the #1 special pho which is the most common pho bowl there is. Well, the beef slices tasted so bad that my body literally tells me to stop eating it. It just tasted like spoiled beef. Then, the dish with bean sprouts for you to dump into your pho is terribly oxidized it changed to brownish color. So I tried to just eat the pho so that I can get out of there without being too disrespectful, but that's when I keep hearing someone coughing and coughing within the kitchen. It is not normal cough, it is the get that mucus out of your throat and spit it out cough. RUN AWAY!
author: Janey C.

description: Love this place! #43 for hot days with a side of imperial rolls and #1 for chilly days with a side of spring rolls. It's a family business, you'll see the kids and the baby!
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Pho Tai was decent - broth had strong star anise flavor, which I like, but beef wasn't rare, which I prefer. Goi Cuon was mediocre - pork tasted slightly porky, but not in a good way. 

If I lived here I'd come back, but since I'm here on vacation I'll probably try Another place.
author: matthew s.

description: I wanted to like this place a whole lot more than I did.  Since I'd not been here before, ordered my standard grilled pork and cha gio over vermacelli noodles.  The pork was dry and was not grilled.  It looked like it was sliced off a pork butt and dredged in ground lemongrass and spices.  The rolls were fine, but, you get a scant 1 or maybe two sliced on top.  More noodles than lettuce and other garnishes.  A little pickled carrot, a few scallions, no mint or basil.  Cash only, service was okay and the place seemed clean.  Sadly, an hour after lunch, not feeling so great, this is not a good sign.
author: Donna H.

description: Came here for lunch and had the Hu Tiey Bo Kho (Beef Stew).  The broth was delicious, a fair amount of meat, and good portion size.  Haven't tried the Pho but will definitely back for the stew.
author: Cody P.

description:
Golden King - I really wanted to like you, I really did - BUT you continue to disappoint me and I really do not know why?  I am polite, patient and give good tips.  So why were my last two take-out orders amiss?

Amiss Nos. 1 - I ordered the #45 (Bun Cha Gio Bo Nuong grilled lemon grass beef and imperial rolls with vermicelli)  and evidently you did not have beef that day (strange), so you offered me the option of chicken or pork.  Me not being a supporter of the slaughter of those cute little, albeit VERY INTELLIGENT pink fuzzy things we humans call pigs, I opted for the chicken (and yes, I am aware of the inhumane treatment of chickens too).

When I got back to my office, I eagerly opened the lunch tray and to my surprise, I found that I did NOT get what I ordered.  WTF?  

I was really looking forward to the imperial rolls - it is the only time I allow myself to splurge on something fried; imagine my disappointment.

In thinking more about what I received - I remember just 15 minutes before I was studying your menu and thought perhaps you may have substituted my order of #45 for the # 47(Bun Ga Xao Sa (Tom, Dau Hu) - Stir Fried Onion Lemon Grass Chicken With Vermicelli choice of shrimp or fried bean cake), and then I was further disappointed in realizing that not only was I short-changed once, but twice - I didn't get the shrimp or fried bean cake (I would have been fine with either).

Oh well - I dealt with it and ate what I did get.

Amiss Nos. 2

Today I went to Big Apple Grocer and purchased myself a BIG soup bowl so I can indulge in tasty soups from all the tasty restaurants along Kearny Street and in China town.

I was short on time and recalled that I had made notes of your menu on my blackberry - so while on the way back to work I called and placed my order for the #20 (Pho Ga & Tai chicken & slices of beef rib eye noodle soup).  The nice woman who took my order repeated what I ordered and confirmed "the chicken & beef with rice noodles" - I said yes, exactly.

I picked up my order, even left a $2 tip (for pick-up to-go items, I think that is a generous tip).  I went back to work, cleaned my pretty new soup bowl and then went through the process of placing the items of the #20 in my bowl.  To my SURPRISE, what I found was about 16 oz of very delicious broth, a small portion of incredibly thinly sliced beef and about the size of my index finger of shredded chicken, 3 thinly sliced peppers and bean sprouts.  In addition, I asked before leaving for chili sauce and was informed that everything was in the bag.  Hah, jokes on me because what was supposed to have been mixed with chili was actually only the plum sauce and no sriracha (and everyone who knows me knows I love me some sriracha).  

Again, I ask; WTF?  

Golden King I really wanted to like you - but for now, I think I will continue my quest for delicious tasty soups and search elsewhere.  Maybe next time I'll go to Have a Rice Day for some delicious noodle soup (even they are more generous with the amount of beef they put in their soups).

Minor update - not only was my Pho disappointing, but evidently the soup it is made with MSG - I know because I have allergic reactions to MSG.  So now 30 minutes later I am I sitting at my desk with a bloated belly and having difficulty in breathing through my nose.  Argh!  This may very well prevent me from ever ordering soup from Golden King again.  8^(  

Breathing is vitally essential to my well being and every day health.
author: Cris B.

description:
It does seem a shame that Golden King is viewed as the ugly stepsister to Golden Star across the street. At least I assume they're joined at the hip since they share the same menu. But is this a case of Cinderella wearing dirty undies beneath her Vera Wang knock-off gown? I'm not sure what I meant either...but yes, the ambiance at Golden King is a bit on the dank side compared to Golden Star. Yet, Golden King has a health inspection code of 96, while Golden Star scored just a 90. Can it be that perhaps the glass slipper is on the wrong foot, your Highness?

Hmmm, not really. There isn't a hugely marked difference in the pho served at both places, but I do feel I don't get as hearty a bowl of goodness at Golden King. Maybe it's the haphazard way the place looks or the overwhelming use of formica or the plethora of plastic plants. I can't quite put my finger on it, but like many others, I come here when the line goes out the door at Golden Star. As usual, I was in a hurry for lunch today and ordered the $6.50 Pho Ga Dai, which is really a big bowl of chicken noodle soup (see my photo). Hmmm, not bad but not that special either.

I had to share a table with a spiky-haired youngster who kept yelling into his cell phone in Cantonese. My God, the 80's are over, my boy. Nope, we didn't bond.... So the Prince may prefer the skinny girl with the smudge on her face over the fat broad with the flat feet, but perhaps that fat broad wouldn't leave the Prince to play with the pool boy at a Sandals resort on their honeymoon. Again, I'm not sure what I meant either ...but hey, I guess I would pick Cinderella after all 'cause you don't care if ugly walks out on ya.

FOOD - 3 stars...passable pho
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...kinda on the dank side, even for Chinatown
SERVICE - 3 stars...speedy without the how-ya-doin' warmth
TOTAL - 3 stars...gee, if I didn't have that stupid meeting at 1pm, I would wait in line at Golden Star
author: Ed U.

description:
Walking up and down Clay street, how come I never really noticed this Vietnamese restaurant?  Well, my friend brought me here and he said it's the only 1 of 2 Vietnamese places he likes in the area. So, I'm game.

I notice the prices seem a bit more and don't have a whole lot of time to peruse the menu because it's lunch and I have to order quick.  I pick #2 ($5.00),  which is the pho with everything except the beef balls.  My friend orders #1 ($5.45), which is everything, of course!

They also give you individual plates of bean sprouts, jalapenos, green stuff, and lime, so you can pretty much take the plate and dump everything in your bowl without feeling like you're a hog or getting everything all over the table during the transfer part from plate to bowl.

When my bowl arrived, I understood why the prices were more - it was the BIG bowl!  (Not the gigantic one at some places!)  Well, it was a big enough bowl for me at least!  I usually get the smaller version when they offer two sizes.  And there was a butt load of noodles in there!  They definitely weren't skimpy on that!

Service was standard.  The waitress took our order, brought our orders quickly to the table, gave our check at a decent time, and our bowls were taken away when we finished.  The place was clean overall, and had a mix of people dining there.

I would go back.  I didn't leave hungry and the place was pretty decent.  Perhaps the star ratings would go up if I tried a few of their other dishes as well.

Update! 09/14/07 - Went back last week for lunch on a Friday and it was packed!  We ordered the spring rolls and the five spice chicken dish.  The spring rolls were fresh and tasty.  The five spice chicken was okay, not as good as PPQ on Irving though.  The egg roll that came with my chicken dish though was really good.  It reminded me of Chinese sticky rice at a dim sum restaurant, but deep fried.  I think I'll have to order the egg rolls as an appetizer the next time.  

(I added pics of my eating in the business profile section!)
author: Teri C.

description:
Avoid this place if you can! I suffered awful food poisoning from my lunch yesterday that lasted all night and through this morning. I had item #41 (vermicelli bowl with fried egg rolls). Like many Asian restaurants, don't expect the raw veggies to be cleansed very well and know that you can be exposed to bacteria and pesticides. The vermicelli noodles in my dish were slimy and wet and the spring rolls were on the burnt side. The pho is also of very poor quality and meats were not fresh. 

Lastly, beware of any restaurant that has a kitchen in the basement and a huge trash receptacle by the back restroom. Thanks, but no thanks!
author: Carmina B.

description:
My husband and I were in China town for the Chinese New Year parade and it was crazy! Most restaurants were a 45 min wait.... We happen to come across this pho restaurant and decided to try it.
We didn't have to wait because they were so fast cleaning up tables for the next customer. 

There's only one size pho bowel I would say large it's huge and only  $7.65. We shared one bowel and it was more than enough. We also ordered the spring rolls and they were super good but instead of ordering one they come with two so you have to pay more and I wasn't feeling the sriracha in the peanut sauce :/

One thing I can complain is the tea in the pot was kinda cold. 

We got ok service but can't blame them due to the full house because of the parade. They were running like crazy to try to attend and fit more customers. We paid exactly 20$ with tip for our dinner .
author: Rosa H.

description: Great imperial rolls and pho broth. This is a great place for a quick lunch especially because Tam's Parking Lot is right across the street for the out-of-towners.
author: Rory T.

description:
Decent pho for roughly $8-9 after tax - not amazing, not terrible, middle of the pack. Definitely not one of the cleaner places around, but this is Chinatown, so keep your sanitation expectations low. First thing I found when I opened up my menu was a dead fly...great start. Got the #1 house special which is basically a beef based pho - includes beef meatballs, beef tendon, tripe and lean skirt steak. Broth is average, nothing to write home about. I was just relieved I didn't find any vermins or hairs in my bowl. I highly recommend inspecting the utensils and condiment bottles at your table before digging in. Bringing some alcohol wipes would not be a bad thing. They're a tad skimpy on the bean sprouts, so you can definitely ask for more. They also don't offer cilantro or limes, which is a letdown. Service is adequate...typical Asian service - they put you at a table, take your order and bring your food. They're not going to ask your how your day is or would you like more water/tea, so if you're one of those sensitive people, just avoid this place or the majority of Asian places not named PF Chang's. Regular tea is complimentary, the fancier ones are not. 

There are better pho places around the area, so I wouldn't settle for this place; but if you don't feel like waiting, it's an acceptable spot.
author: Jeff S.

description: This pace has fast service and its pretty cheap with good portions for the pho. I generally get the #1 and its good, but not great. Not a bad choice and a good go-to when you want something in the area.
author: Richard L.

description:
This is usually my second option when Golden Star, which is just across the street, is packed.   I usually order the Grilled Beef/egg rolls vermicelli at both places.  The portions may be just slightly smaller at Golden Star but quality is better there, thus the crowd/lines during peak hours at lunch.  

Yesterday, there was a crowd at Golden Star and I had to rush, so I strolled into Golden King as usual and got a bowl of gristle.   The beef in my bowl tasted unmarinated and more than half filled with inedible pieces of beef.  Pissed me off! I would give them 1 star for my experience yesterday but they have fed me other times satisfactorily.  This is the last time I am going there for fear of more gristles.  Funny how a one time lousy experience can put me off so much that I do not want to go back there again.
author: Anna C.

description: Next time I come back here I am getting the five spice chicken. . . such comfort food. I had to steer away from the pho this time, so I opted for something for healthy BUN lol. I got the grilled pork and shrimp with vermicelli. of course i put some extra sriracha in  the nuoc man (sp?). and i had some of the hubbz imperial roll. one of the best i've tasted in the long time. and you can really tell if the place hasn't changed their frying oil. when the baby makes her appearance, i am going to go back and get me some bun bo hue. and winter will be the perfect time for it too!! plus their hot tea is really really delicious.
author: Maureen M.

description:
[M]ona: 3 Stars
[W]ayne: 3.5 Stars
Average: 3.25 Stars

+ Inexpensive

- Service
- Cash Only
 
[W] We came here because the Vietnamese place across the street was too packed. After all, this was the Chinese festival weekend and I was expecting everywhere to be busy but not this place.....so we tried it out. It wasn't too bad actually. We ordered the hot Vietnamese coffee http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4HeUBskEaGZ2qlnGtBcy7A?select=fRaop7aP6gesB8j9Yn3UNQ, the chicken curry http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4HeUBskEaGZ2qlnGtBcy7A?select=QR9-OpS1LaGigMifJx6elA, and BBQ pork vermicelli with imperial rolls http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4HeUBskEaGZ2qlnGtBcy7A?select=7ky4_Vh-iQhIlKRHOHHvxw. The weird thing was that for the hot tea, they gave the condensed milk with the tea dripping on top and a hot water mug for the water. I'm sure a lot of you are like, whats wrong with that? But for some reason it doesn't seem very restaurant like I suppose?
 
The chicken curry was kinda good. But like all Chinese/Vietnamese places, they usually make it out of powdered curry which taste kind of pasty. I don't know how to explain it but it definitely tastes like there was no effort to making this dish. The vermicelli on the other hand was good like it always is. If you've ever ate a vermicelli at a vietnamese spot, then I suppose they all taste the same.
 
Service in Chinatown are usually non-existant. When we got in they're kind of attentive, then when it got a little busier, obviously bye bye service and time to flag everyone down.
author: Mona C.

description:
Despite the subpar service (waitresses took such a long time to even take our order), I am still inclined to give Golden King four stars because of the sheer amount of beef and noodles in the Beef Noodle Stew. You get many large chunks of beef in a spicy broth (non-spicy eaters beware, or ask for milder flavored broth).

One thing that bugs me about this place is that the beansprouts served with the noodle soups aren't "cleaned". The beansprouts all have the roots still attached while most restaurants spend time serving their customers cleaned beansprouts. I thought that would affect my meal but thankfully it didn't.
author: Jason T.

description:
Why are so many vietnamese places Golden something? And I swear this place used to be called Golden Ostrich...

Food isn't bad here and portions are hefty. I got the lemongrass pork with cha gio (you can choose to have an egg instead). Mom got the lemongrass chicken and she did note that it seemed smaller than before. Definitely lots o' pork on my dish, but it is true that the slices seemed kinda jerky like. And a little less nuoc cham than I like, but I stole Mom's and she indicated that the place is just happy to give you more if you ask.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I thought the food here was pretty good. I don't usually get vietnamese food in chinatown, but it was open and I was hungry so I picked some stuff up with my wife and kid.

The shrimp and pork rice paper roll was quite good. And harder to find nowadays, most places usually make it with just shrimp now. And the peanut sauce has a little kick to it. Overall a great appetizer.

I got the combo beef #1 and my wife got the chicken pho. She commented that the chicken pho was quite tasty. I didn't try it; normally I would but she has a cold so I was off-limits. The beef pho was good - lots of beef goodies in there and the broth was flavorful. The pho itself had a nice texture, although the rice flavor was a bit strong for me. Overall though it is probably something I'll order again.

We also got the grilled pork chop with rice, and the pork chop was grilled perfectly - still moist and tender. I've been to too many places that burn that sucker to a crisp, and GK does a nice job. 

A nice place that I will come back to.
author: Dom L.

description: 5 stars for customer service! I ordered a beef stew without knowing it was spicy. I asked the owner and he said yes, it is. I said I have a cough and he immediately took the stew and told me to order something else. I told him it's ok a couple of times but he insisted. It's really nice to see an owner in Chinayown that cares about their customers and not just money.
author: Rachel C.

description: The noodles were soggy and the soup had a weird taste to it. HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE. We walked in and they didn't bother asking us how many people are with us and we had to sit ourselves down at a table. When we were about to order the waitress just left and gave a loud "I'll be back. " When the food finally came, the complimentary dish of bean sprouts,jalapeño, lime etc. weren't offered. Long story short, the customer service was horrible. I wouldn't come back to this pho place ever again
author: Kiki M.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE !!!!! this  is my favorite pho place in sf.  I love their Bun Bo Hue, I get it everytime I go there. since Ive been there so often I dont even have to tell the boss what im going to get ... they are also super friendly !
author: amy l.

description:
Just revisited this ph restaurant near Portsmouth Square in Chinatown for lunch and it's still the same...excellent!

Had the #2 c Bit (Special) and it was super-yummy!  Came out hot and the broth was not overly sweet or rich but beefy indicating to me an absence of msg which is terrific!  Fair amount of beef and other meats.  Plate of sprouts, basil and lemon were fresh and fragrant.

Service was very attentive and the decor was clean and traditional.  Server was standing nearby in case anyone needed anything.
author: Coy T.

description: Came here with my family (8 people) and we came before lunch time. By the time we got our food, we were waiting for our drinks. Three of us finished eating already before the water arrived. Drank mostly tea to help the food go down. Service and food is great but they might need more workers during the busy hours.
author: MaiNra V.

description:
The pho bo kho here is amazing!  Check out the photo I posted of it!! 

My lunch crew always used to go to Golden Star across the street, but since it's so busy, we've started coming to Golden King, and I'm so glad we did!  I always used to get the regular beef pho at Vietnamese restaurants, but because of Golden King, I discovered the magic of pho bo kho.  It has thicker, spicy broth, and has huge chunks of delicious beef.  

This spot has also gotten very busy lately (the crowds probably followed us from Golden King!), so go a bit earlier if you intend to go during the lunch hour.  

Say it with me now... PHO BO KHO!!!
author: James C.

description:
The skinny:

good pho
nice people
comfy seating
author: Chris G.

description: Hu tieu bo kho is the best noodle soup I ever had.
author: WonderingCloud C.

description: Golden King is a staple Pho place in Chinatown. I always order the #2 Pho Without Beef Balls.   It has the perfect soup base with fresh ingredients and a side dish of lemons and basil to top it all off. The meat to noodle ratio is fair, filling me up after a workout on the weekends. Service is extremely fast and friendly. The seating is comfortable and very spacious.
author: Edward G.

description:
I only come here for one thing:  the pho bo kho (beef stew pho).  It's a thick and spicy beef stew pho. The cuts of meat are beef and some of it has the fat on it which is yummy in a savory type of stew like this.  

It's absolutely delicious!  One time I came here with a friend and they were out.  I was very, very sad. :( I ordered another pho and it was good, but I wanted my pho bo kho!  I came back with another friend the next week and was happy.  They give you a lot, so it's something you can split.  When I know I'm coming here, I just don't eat breakfast.

They're also pretty nice. That makes going to a small place like this fun.  There you go! I've pretty much said go there and order the pho bo kho, but don't order a lot of it on the days that I plan on eating there. ;)
author: Regina W.

description: Went here for lunch with some coworkers who are superfans. The flank steak pho was probably the most delicious, flavorful pho I've ever had. It was very large and I couldn't imagine finishing the broth. They served us very quickly, though they mixed up our orders (apparently they often do). Prices were very good for lunch. I'll return.
author: Luke K.

description: Conveniently located on clay street in Chinatown just shy away from the main streets. Lunch hours are PACKED. Price wise its affordable but a little on the pricier end. The food is okay. The dac biet had a whole bunch of msg in it...not my liking I've better but it's a quick fix. Broth has a lot of msg. No bueno!
author: Anita L.

description:
The Vietnamese beef stew noodle soup is the best in a sea of noodle house restaurant.  The flavor is spot on and they really listen to their customers.

My friend and I always ask for the lean beef stew meats....yeah, I know the fat tendons are suppose to taste the best.  But, we always get what we ask for and fills your tummy with yummy. 

It is a great hang over dish so I hear.  Got to check out their other dishes, as I had the curry chicken tofu over rice prior.  They nailed that one as it was not on the menu and had it made special.  

Overall a very great value that whips up delicious food and delivers attentive service.
author: Rocky S.

description: If you are cold, tired, or hungry in SF, the pho at Golden King will cure what ails you. They are definitely family friendly, yet I was welcomed as a single diner at the community table on a busy afternoon. The pho - amazing. Try the succulent five-spice chicken pho. A generous portion of crispy chicken is served next to a huge bowl of flavorful pho, and you are provided the usual side dish of condiments, including basil, bean sprouts, a big wedge of lime, and jalapeño slices. It is located in the heart of Chinatown, so there are many sights to see right outside the door. This is a casual restaurant that delivers big on food and flavor. The owners and server were all warm and helpful when I had questions. Really, really delicious!
author: msue A.

description:
I could go on and on about my love of SF and Chinatown most of all, but after trying several different pho places in my 3 days there I stumbled into this little gem of a restaurant after resting my feet at Portsmouth square. Not much in the way of décor, I was the only white girl in there, I was given hot tea and a bowl of pho and left completely alone. 
These are all good, nay, great things.
I had the pho tai with the meat served on the side..I like it more raw than cooked and lemme tell you the broth was phoking goooood! Full of flavor and the noodles were perfectly done. Now if I can find a place this good in Dallas..
author: Kristin F.

description: Service was so bad and so slow that I left after 20 min of waiting for my food without eating.
author: Ohhh Y.

description: As some reviewer mentioned, #18 is great. Don't walk away without eating #18. It's not the best place for Pho but it's the best that I found close to Financial District.
author: Ryosuke K.

description:
I had the seafood noodle dish.  Very tasty!!

Great location (near a park and Grant St. where I had done some shopping).   

The place was hopping at lunch time and full to the brim -- a good sign I thought as I had never been here before -- they did their best to make sure I didn't wait and I was happy with the food.
author: Roni K.

description:
I came here by myself, and they sat me in the back at a large round table with some random dudes.  Look, I either want to eat alone, or with someone I know and like, so I HATE it when restaurants (except for cafeterias and dim sum places) spring the "communal eating/seating" set up on you.

I thought they were leading me to a table in the back, and they were, just one that happened to have a couple of people already there.  I felt duped and considered walking out, but I was hungry, so I stayed.

I shouldn't have stayed. I got the chicken pho ("#16").  The broth wasn't very hot, and there wasn't much chicken. It was the kind of pho that has a bunch of lettuce leaves in it, and I've noticed that places that do the "lettuce leaf thing" almost always have sub-par pho.  Golden King was no exception.  Maybe they use the lettuce leaves to hide the fact that they skimped on the meat! 

I prefer my lunch hour to be my hour of calm and solitude.  I'm already a messy eater who uses a ton of napkins and gets all slurpy and runny-nosed when I eat pho, so the last thing I really need are a couple of strangers that I feel obligated to be all ladylike in front of.
author: Karen F.

description:
for the longest time ive thought that SF has noo good pho until i started working in chinatown and this became a regular pho place for me. 

i really like the pho here! it comes with a good amount of noodles and meat and great broth (doesn't leave me with that after taste and where im chugging cups and cups of water afterwards)

i come at least once every 1-2 weeks and have not gotten a disappointing bowl yet. and it's been perfectttt for these freezing cold days we've been experiencing lately.
author: Katherine C.

description: Best pho noodles I've had in town. Note: I haven't tried too many of the top-rated restaurants on yelp but I've worked my way around a number of pho restaurants in the city "back in my day" lol. It is a little pricy but I like how the pho noodles are cooked just right and just the way I like it. It's crisp enough not to the point where it's raw or that it absorbs the soup too quickly where it will end up soggy. And their meatballs are pretty huge and delish.
author: Sophia K.

description: Went here with my husband and a good friend while visiting SF.  Was such a great find....   The food reminded me of when I lived in SE Asia and brought me back to the authentic food tastes I've missed.  It's a must do.  No frills but well worth it and at an excellent price!!!
author: Karen S.

description:
1) Hit ATM
2) Order #5
3) Wait 90 seconds for food to arrive, and inhale.

I've hit quite a few pho places in my time in SF, and this one truly is at the top of my books.  I generally like mine southern style with lime (I think this is right?) but these guys are doing everything else textbook for me.  Quality cuts, great broth, and FAST.  If I order pho and i'm in the restaurant for more than 30 min, there is something seriously wrong.  In my quest for pho domination, this has been a monumental step for the city of SF.
author: William B.

description:
Used to come here very often right after playing some basketball at CC, but now since CC is closed I barely head to Chinatown anymore. Everyone I know loves this place and when we mention pho this is the only place that comes to mind, no where else. 

I loved this place when I first tried it but then as time went on the taste just went downhill. It tasted like they put more water in their broth or something because the flavor sucked more and more. One day I went, I noticed they changed their noodles to a cheaper and more lighter noodle and started charging 50 cent more for every dish.

This place has two entrances, this confused me when I came here the first time. Their interior is pretty chill, the seats are comfortable and it's never crowd, at least the times I go there.

Their pho is really big especially when you add extra noodles, I only finished it once out of around 6 times. I never tried any other dishes besides their beef pho because I always craved so much after playing basketball for couple of hours.

Now, I rather up Golden Star and get quality over quantity.
author: Hui L.

description:
Golden King - I am not a fan. You are like the bad step sibling of Golden Star and Golden Flower. 

I believed in you for some time and I know there are ties between you and the Star, but in the end, you fall short. The broth is not as good and it's dirtier. Yes, dirty. Ever since the day I found a shrimp shell in my beef pho, I cannot eat as freely. You were a go to pho place because Golden Star was too packed and you could fit my colleagues and I. My non-asian colleagues cannot tell the difference between the pho of the Golden Trio, and most people can't so it's no knock on them. Unfortunately I can and you are the odd one out.
author: Eddie L.

description:
This place is good stand-by if you go to the one around the corner Golden Star Vietnamese, which in my opinion has superior broth.  That place fills up at noon pretty quickly, so the Golden King (not Star) is good to go to if you find yourself on the long waiting list.  Their Pho is good and a good fill-in for the other place.  
Cash only, so don't show them your plastic or you'll go hungry
author: Greg R.

description:
I passed on the iconic #1 (the extra large beef noodle soup) and instead ordered the #40 (pork chop and chicken over rice), a less iconic dish, but satisfying enough for any carnivorous appetite. 

I was definitely impressed by the portion size, the large pork chop and huge chicken thigh. The fish dipping sauce it came with complimented the meat well. 

The flies buzzing on our table? And the object that looked like hair in my friend's food? Both pretty gross, but not too surprising considering this is a typical restaurant you find in Chinatown. 

You come here for the quick service and cheap food. And for those aforementioned reasons, you try and ignore all other faults. If you are OCD clean or are extremely bougie this is not the place for you. 

Eat here if you have no choice, but you have been warned.
author: Allan Y.

description:
Big, fat, thick hair in food. DO NOT WANT. 

Loud, rude, and hair-infused. So disgusting. The waitress showed lots of class, interrupting my ordering to yell at another waitress in front of the entire restaurant and calling her a, 'stupid idiot' (in Cantonese). Apparently the other waitress forgot the body hair. 

Seriously, it's not that hard to prevent hair from falling into food. It's a well-known and easily solved problem, but in Chinatown, the hit rate for keratin boosts to your food is probably 1/3. Sigh.
author: A B.

description:
I used to visit this place a lot during the summer with my friends. It was THE place to grab a big bowl of pho and leave full. It doesn't take that long to get your order, and every time I came down to visit it wouldn't have to wait.

I never tried the other things on their menu, but that's because you really come here just for the pho. I hear from my friend though, that recently they've raised their prices and the broth in the pho tastes watered down. I couldn't tell after visiting from my long absence, but the price went up a dollar or so.

I wouldn't say it's the best place to get pho, but I definitely enjoyed the meal every time I dropped by.
author: Richard C.

description: Like many places the food has a large amount of msg. Had the #1 which was $7. It was a medium-large bowl. When I first tasted the pho it was very good but I'm thinking "this must have tons of msg" -totally true because afterwards I was extremely thirsty!!! The soup was very oily and the beef was very fat. Even though I didn't pay for this meal I still think it was expensive for something with so much msg, oil and fat. I also did not like the atmosphere so much. The owners/workers had their child at the restaurant like its a day care center. I'm trying to eat and I would prefer not to have a child running around; its annoying. If i want pho/vietnamese again I would stick to Golden Star.
author: Carmen L.

description:
The best Phö I've ever had! I'm coming back to SF just to eat here. It will be worth the drive from Modesto. 
They could use some chili sauce and some lemon grass chili. Food was amazing!
Bring cash...no credit cards accepted.
author: P E.

description: I love you Golden King.  I love your hot, steamy, spicy bowls of pho.  I love your quick, friendly service.  I love your location so close to my office.  I don't care that you are cash-only or that sometimes the spoons are a little dirty.  I just love that you provide a tasty, speedy bowl of yumminess for lunch.   Get the #21 with pork chop.
author: Jen B.

description:
Tasty enough to fix my bun chay cravings, tucked far enough from the FiDi to be forgotten by 9-5'ers, big enough to get you back to work with some of that lunch hour to spare.  Or use the extra fifteen minutes to walk thru the park and check out the rowdy card games and gossip outside the Chinatown community center.   

Service is like most authentic Vietnamese joints if you're not Vietnamese--more efficient than doting.  Cleaner, nicer, and a little more expensive than the 'loin, but just about right for a downtown lunch.  Unless you like eating in a wind tunnel, avoid sitting near the door.
author: Dana S.

description:
I arrived in San Francisco this morning, checked in to the hotel, changed, and made a b-line with my co-worker. My co-worker is a SF native and this is his regular joint. I happened to be nursing a cold and even lost my voice this morning. I sound like I could go to Pier 39 and have a meaningful conversation with the sea lions. But pho was my driving force since I woke up this morning and it was satisfied.

We began with the spring rolls $6. They were fat with noodles, shrimp, thai basil, and pork. The peanut sauce had a hint of chili paste that was a good contrast to the nuttiness.

The pho noodles were actually chewy, just the way I like it, and there were a lot of it. The tendon was a bit broken up, but the tripe was abundant. I just really needed something hot to soothe my cold and it hit the spot. It just sucks being sick in San Francisco.
author: Steve Y.

description: Great Pho, great imperial rolls, and a great price!  A fantastic place to regroup after a big night.
author: Daryn L.

description:
This place gets my *BEST VIET/CHINESE FOOD* in Chinatown. It's definitely not PURE Vietnamese (I mean, everyone there speaks Cantonese, don't be silly), but the meats are fresh, and the drinks are YUMZ, with the intentional "z". 

TAKE AWAYS: 
- Seating is plentiful, bring groups if you want. 
- The prep time IS SOOO FAST. If you have a date, prepare to know about each other with mouths full. Impress her with the food, not the decor. 
- The drinks (even simple things like the orange juice), have a nice, fresh take on them. I'd come here just to grab something to sip on. 

I've actually been here a few times, and it's growing on me. I'll see you there! 

NOTE: Their waitresses sometimes stare at you, which is awkward turtle, but hey. You can always get their attention...better too much than too little methinks?
author: Abel L.

description: It's ok. Good cheap bowl of pho and OK price.  Menu wasn't different from the other hundred Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Troy V.

description:
Let me give you a little background. I am Vietnamese, have a mother in law that'll cook the best pho you'll ever taste in your life, and I am a well seasoned pho aficionado. 

I ordered an egg roll appetizer, and a Pho Bo Vien. The egg rolls were surprisingly good, hence the 2 stars you see above. 

The Pho Bo Vien was bad, and here's why. The broth was riddled with MSG, and even with MSG, there was hardly any flavor to the broth. It tasted like they took beef stock, mixed it with MSG, forgot to warm it up, and then served it. The beef balls were flavorless, and tasted as though I was eating rubber flavored shrimp. Even the pho vermicelli wasn't satisfying because taste and texture of the noodle felt wrong.

My gut was telling me Golden King skimped on choosing quality ingredients and settled for the cheap stuff. Later on, my heart was telling me I had too much MSG. Felt like I was going to have a heart attack. If you're looking for some decent pho, go across the street and visit Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant. Try the 5 spice chicken pho.
author: Tri N.

description:
good - super hot soup with my pho
bad - only cliantro and bean sprouts. no basil with my pho
the aight - the noodles were of proper texture. the rib eye slices were lean but overcooked in the super hot broth. next time I will ask for the beef on the side. it was a good dining experience overall and I would not hesitate to come back.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Came here last Friday for lunch with a bunch of coworkers. We decided to try it out because our usual spot (golden star) that's across the street was super packed, and we didn't feel like waiting. This is a bigger location, and no wait! 

I ordered the chicken with imperial rolls with vermicelli. I thought the chicken was going to in pieces, but it was this giant chicken leg...so I had to borrow the knife my coworker was using for his pork chop to get through my chicken leg. It was very flavorful tho! Imperial rolls were delicious, I enjoyed that the most. The sauce that comes with the cold noodle wasn't that good - tasty saltier than normal. My coworkers did comment that the pho was better across the street.

Service was okay here...I felt like they were trying to rush us. And I had to remind them to get our water. But it was lunch time, and that can get really busy. At least they got all our orders right!  Overall not bad- quick, good, cheap, and clean.
author: Betty S.

description: Solid Pho at a reasonable price.  The Beef Stew is especially good if you like a spicy heavily flavored broth.  This is my go-hto place for Pho near the financial district.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I ordered #1 and it was good but I was hoping for more beef slices. All ingredients were tasty and with plenty of sprouts and basil leaves. With the iced coffee it's about 13 dollars. Not bad at all. Obviously it is hard to compare with  the ones in the Little Saigon or Tenderloin.

Fast service though it gets crowded and you might have to share a table or wait.
author: T L.

description:
They have the best pho in Chinatown.
They also have the best imperial rolls. You know those spring roll like things. You should order the cold vermicelli bowl with imperial rolls and your choice of meat. This bowl is like a salad bowl. It's huge! I can't even finish it and it's so good! It's worth it for that price about 8 bucks. I think the order number on the menu is around the #35...forgot.
author: Annie H.

description:
Ok, this is my new place to go for Vietnamese food.  Co-workers love to go to the Golden Star across the street, and not sure why.  

Golden King has a much wider selection, cleaner, and not so damn tight seating.  All those are big pluses in my book.

I ordered the Lemongrass beef w/ imperial rolls, egg, rice.  Good amount of beef and it was thinly sliced...just as I like.  I'd definitely be returning to try some of their pho.
author: Michelle N.

description:
I've eaten pho on a regular basis for the better part of 25 years - prepared by professionals and home cooks alike.  Having said that, the House Special Pho at Golden King Vietnamese Restaurant ranks among the worst I've ever had.  

I write this none too lightly, as I've eaten noodle soups under some of the most unsanitary circumstances, for example, at a dock alongside the Mekong River where the helper girl rinsed (not washed with soap and clean water) my bowl out in the same river before serving said noodle soup, and it wasn't half bad.  However, that was among the times I had to rely on an open mind, strong stomach acids, and a hardy immune system.

In this case, my expectations of their pho were high, based on previous reviews and consequently, I was unprepared to have to arm myself with my usual trinity.  And, because I've never known Yelpers to be so far off in their assessment, it makes this experience especially disappointing.

Broth: meaty, but had a strange, off-putting curry or clove flavor

Noodles: al dente, a little hard; I prefer chewier noodles

Meat breakdown:
  Ribeye - chewy & kinda gross
  Flank - pretty good
  Tendon - again, pretty good
  Tripe- hard & chewy
  Meatballs - slimy & REALLY gross

Bottom line: I do NOT recommend this place, nor will I go back.
author: vira k.

description:
Cheap pho. You can't go wrong. Kbye. 

Always always always get the number 1. Why? Because it's special. Duh.
author: Melissa T.

description: This place is steadily busy at lunch, but the wait is not unbearable.  The five spice chicken pho is pretty good.  The imperial rolls are not very good unfortunately.  They came hot and crispy, but the filling did not much flavor.  The dipping sauce had no zip and I could not detect any fish sauce.
author: Amber B.

description:
I recently came here with my father right before we went to a Chinese Tea Ceremony at the Chinese Cultural Center.  He loves pho.  I love pho.  The pho in the East Bay is dirty, more expensive and smaller portions.  I knew this place was nearby so all things worked out well.

There was some thing going on in the park with the Chinese instruments that have only 2 strings and a very organic, textural quality.  

Inside, the place was fairly clean and well lit.  It was not very crowded but that's because the service was quick and the tables were turned over several times.  

I got the rare steak with tendon (steak on the side).  The broth was a bit salty and lacked that strong herbal, spiced aroma.  The meat was good quality and the tendon was nice and thick.  I liked it a lot.  I do not like the thin sliced tendon because it practically disintegrates in the hot broth.  The restaurant did not have fish sauce at the tables but they brought it over when we asked.

After eating, they let my father and I sit around while I programmed his new phone.  It was a bonding moment.  I gave him a new telephone, I switched my mother's number to my father's old phone.
author: Christina C.

description:
we had a group of 10 and they seated us promptly.  the pho place around the corner seemed a lot more crowded.  but i definitely like it when i dont have to wait.  i got the seafood pho when almost everyone else got the beef stew.  the seafood pho was good.  the broth was good.  i drank it all. and i ate all the fish balls, fake crab, and shrimp.  by then i was a bit too full to eat pho.  so when i got to it it had gotten soggy.  but it probably wasnt in the beginning.

bathroom is also pretty clean!
author: claudia y.

description:
I eat here anywhere from once to four times a week.  Suffice it to say that the pho is good enough to make me a repeat customer.  This is not the best pho in San Francisco, but it is the best pho within walking distance of my work.

People seem to love Golden Star more than Golden King.  I think the two places are comparable.  The pho at Golden King has better broth, but I will give Golden Star credit for having superior quality meat (especially the steak and the brisket).  I frequent Golden Star as well, but the ratio of trips to King versus Star is about 4 to 1.  I guess broth is more important to me.

The bun and the rice plates are also pretty good, not the best, but definitely passable for a working stiff like me.
author: David C.

description:
I always order the same thing when I eat viet food. Chicken over rice (5 spice chicken here in Cali) and cha gio (imperial rolls). I prefer my chicken over rice to be heavily marinated and boneless.
