At Golden King, the chicken is bone-in and not heavily marinated. They marinate the chicken (leg and thigh) and then deep fry it. The skin is really flavorful but the meat is just plain chicken meat. It's good, but not as good as the boneless, marinated version that I'm used to. 

The imperial rolls were really good here. They also serve thai iced tea, which obviously isn't viet, but I like eating my viet food with thai iced tea. It was pretty good here. 

The star of the meal was my friend's porkchop over rice. It was heavily marinated and so damn yummy. I kept picking at my friend's food more than mine. 

And the prices here are CHEAP. My kinda place.
author: Jen D.

description:
Where to go for a low-key (aka not Slanted Door) business lunch with 6 people? Not here. Unless, of course, your budget is $40 total, in which case this place is perfect for you. (Note: cash only, but at these prices, you probably have the cost of your meal clanking around in your pocket!)

Not my kind of food (try ordering something without rice or noodles at a Vietnamese restaurant--they look at you like you just got off the crazy boat), but even if I were a big pho-fan, it looks rather average. The rest of my colleagues seemed underwhelmed by their dishes as well. My pork chop and egg were too sweet and greasy and lacking in spice. 

On the plus side, they seated us immediately and the tables weren't so packed together that we couldn't share trade secrets.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Vietnamese is a tricky cuisine - it is either really, really good or it's HORRIBLE.

Those are just the facts.

I have had trouble finding Vietnamese restaurants in SF which I found, personally, palatable.  Imagine my shock when I discovered this little hole in the wall just a block from my very own apartment...

I particularly like the roast pork and shrimp vermicelli dish (#7) and the robust wonton soup.

It is not all great food all the time - it can be hit or miss; however, what they lack in consistency they make up for in expediency and just plain old customer service.

The owners of this restaurant are so friendly to everyone who walks through the door, despite how your food may or may not taste, it is plainly impossible to have a bad dining experience here. 

I give it four and a half stars... it is one of those restaurants which is on my "I worked really late and don't feel like putting any effort into finding dinner" speed dial list...

In fact, I am dining there this evening.
author: Kate R.

description:
I just got back from lunch here with my boss. I am not a big soup kind of girl, but seriously, I love this place. The only reason it isn't getting 5 stars is because I haven't tried many dishes and I don't feel like I can give it a proper 5 stars. 

I usually go before the lunch rush because it can get packed and you stand around staring at people wishing them to be done so you can sit down and order your very own big bowl of soup. 

The #18 is great when you are feeling sick, it is love in a huge bowl of soup. The bowls are big and they don't skimp on any of the the stuff in it, so the prices are excellent.

 I love the noodles, wonton's, shrimp and pork. My co-workers #21 looked awesome today too (mental note for myself) 

Basically, I love it here. I need to go back and try something new so I can give it 5 stars.
author: Jessica R.

description: I ordered the house beef special like at every pho restaurant I go to.  It was okay, not enough meat in it because mainly the rice noodles over powered it.  But it was a huge bowl for the price I paid for.  My mom had the rice place with pork and over easy eggs. I actually prefer her meal over mine. But anyway, why complain for some cheap food right? Its a bad economy might as well enjoy it. =)
author: Sharjah M.

description:
I noticed a Golden-name theme amongst Vietnamese restaurants in my area.  If I see 'Golden' in the name, I subconsciously think they must serve V-food.

My colleagues and I tried this place after we saw the long queue outside my ol' standby, Golden Star.  Golden King was conveniently across the street with no line, but we did wait a few minutes for a table to clear.  

The space is nicer if you are in the annex room or towards the front of the restaurant.  Bummer we were sat in the back by the open kitchen area, and the stacks of boxes and...toys?  It was like being in a cluttered person's apartment back there.

The food was average. Service was good - not super quick, nor slow.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Pretty decent pho, but I usually get the non-pho dishes here because they are more delicious than the pho bowl....

The  #47 Stir Fried Onion Lemon Grass Vermicelli with Shrimp is my favorite dish here.  It's very garlic-ky but delicious!  Make sure you have gum for the after meal!

The #28, Grilled pork chop with pan fried egg with rice is also very good too!  But I preferred the #47 with Shrimp :) 

Be prepare for slow cashier service :)
author: Gigi T.

description:
Great place to be, if you want to grab a quick lunch....
or to host a great dinner date........

Cause, this place is not your ordinary cheap fast-food restaurant....
They manage to maintain the price at the great rate, but with:

Spacious dinning area, 
Freshly clean hemisphere, 
Decent quality of food, 

If you want great food~ this is the place
If you want to have a full meal with just ONE order~ this is the place
If it is just couple days before the pay-day~ THIS IS THE PLACE! 

Good Restaurant, Good Vietnamese Food~
author: Andrew W.

description:
Good Pho -  very reasonably priced for San Francisco. Very aromatic broth.  The Imperial rolls were second only to my mother's!  The lunch plate of rice, egg, and grilled pork looked very delicious too!

However, no matter where I go in the USA - the best Pho is still in Falls Church, VA - PHO-75, next to Loehmann's Plaza.
author: Ronni E.

description:
Used to come here alot when I used to pick up my wife from work when she worked in the area.  Don't get a chance to come here anymore though.  

What I remember was that they were cheap and they gave a lot of noodles and meat.  It was a great place to go to have a quick dinner cause we used to go right around 5p and there wasn't ever any crowd at that time.  

Quick and Cheap dinner and noodle soup, which in any form, is always one of my favorite things to eat....
author: Mark W.

description:
So I've had a hankerin' for pho lately, but timing and weather hadn't matched up and it remained a nebulous idea floating around the back of my head.  Well, today I decided to do a lunch time wander until I found something to eat when I found myself in front of this place.  Hitting random Chinatown spots is a dicey game to play, but I figured it was worth a shot as the aforementioned hankerin' collided with sudden pangs of hunger.  

I got the 20 (basic chicken and beef pho) and spent the rest of my lunch in soup heaven.  The meat was tender and perfect, the broth fantastic with only minimal application of hot sauce, just enough noodles, and it all came to about $7.  That's a tough deal to beat, IMHO.
author: Steve G.

description: Went with a group of three people for lunch. Placed seemed sanitary enough and staff were friendly. The Pho was great and finished it completely. Everything was good until the end when I was about to pay with my debit card. The waitress told me "Cash only". None of us had enough cash so I had to quickly leave and come back with cash. That inconvenient trip and back ruined it to the point were I wont return again.
author: Thomas B.

description: I used to come to Chinatown all the time and when i would go, I usually ate here. They have pretty good pho. I LOVE their 3 color drink here. They have this semi hard/soft jelly that looks like half a grape in there, so good. Decent price. Nice staff. Food can come out slower when the place is busy but comes out quick when it's not.
author: Annie W.

description: 5 stars because this is one of my childhood spots that my dad used to bring me to eat pho. Good memories. I always get the beef pho or the crispy seafood pan fried noodles, my favorites. I've had pho at many places and the pho here is the best. And this is comparing to the good pho places on Irving too!
author: Linda L.

description:
My Favee vermicelli ! vermicellis my favorite at pho places ! but.. heres the tricky part i ONLY get it here ! 
certainly filled me up for 6.75. i always get the grilled pork+imperial rolls. 2 birds with one stone ! #43 if you must=) 
Their lemon soda is gross though. that was a bummer, but i can get that anywhere! its chinatown..=)
author: Wendy X.

description: Typical Vietnamese offering.  One of the go to spots for Vietnamese food for FiDi employees.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Came here for lunch today with some friends because the line at Golden Star was too long.  Normally I try to get to Golden Star either early or late to avoid the lunch rush, but we missed it today.  So we lowered our expectations and stepped into this joint.  

First off, I don't understand pho places that charge you when you ask for meat on the side.  A $0.50 charge just so I don't have to eat my meat cooked well done?  Are you serious?  

Secondly, unlike Golden Star, they don't have napkins on the tables and maybe we were just too lazy but we didn't bother asking for more either... just took them off the table next to us instead.

The pho was decent...  Not sure what it was, but I prefer the pho at Golden Star.  Maybe it's the broth...  

Anyway, I would come back here, but only as a last resort if Golden Star has a line out the door...
author: Allan H.

description:
OMG. This place is nasty.  DO NOT ORDER THE PHO.  Any pho for that matter. First the noodles get soggy and lax if you don't eat it in 2 mins.  That's not how pho is supposed to be.  The people bringing the pho to you had their thumb in the noodles. Gross.  My brother got food poisoning after eating here.  We think it might be the beef or worse, bean sprouts and or veggies.  We all know how easy bean sprouts can sprout bacteria if they are kept soggy and wet.  

I would not come here ever again.
author: AhLin C.

description: I am always up for Viet food. The portions were pretty big here and no doubt it is yummy! The service was quick and the waiters knew we were not locals. They were really friendly and chatted with us for a few. Would definitely come back for some pho.
author: Sandy C.

description:
I only go here when the line at Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant (literally across the street) is overflowing with thirsty patrons.

However, I will say the pho isn't that bad here.  The 5 spice chicken is a hit or miss (3 out of 5 will be good).  The seafood and beef pho is good, but not great.

The place is kinda dark and dingy, with annoying florescent lighting.  Everything looks blah, but the service is nice.

And again, why the long pinky nails?  What is the meaning of this???
author: Isaac L.

description:
Came here to meet up with a group of friends for lunch. I had the #21 (Five Spice Chicken with Noodle Soup ~$7+). They give you individual plates of the bean sprouts, basil and mint leaves, jalopeno peppers and lime/lemon, which is kind of cool because now I don't have to watch how much I take without someone else screaming obscenities at me for taking too much or too little! Gawd, it NEVER works out either way doesn't it??! Anyways, mines didn't come with a lime! BOO!!! 

The broth was nothing special, but was more on the salty side for me while the Five Spice Chicken was super tough and didn't have much meat on it. The overall taste was so-so. I actually enjoyed my noodle soup rather than my Chicken.

Although all of our dishes arrived quickly, it took a while for my friend to receive her simple Chicken Pho (#16) and it wasn't until we had to ask them about it that it was finally brought out. Despite that everyone else seemed satisfied with their food. 

2 stars because this place was actually clean, but I've had better pho elsewhere.....
author: Serena W.

description:
It's average Chinese-style Vietnamese, which is to say that you can get a bowl of pho relatively cheaply and it's relatively OK.

I go for the #16, soup w/ chicken and egg noodles.  Because the rice noodles are nothing to write home about.

The wait staff isn't great -- they seemingly don't have much to do, but they had to wait for me to ask for a napkin (to clean up remnants of my Vietnamese coffee-to-ice transfer) before I saw a shred of paper come my way.  And oh yeah, I never got the water I asked for.

Points for the plate of sprouts and basil.  I like accessorizing my junk.  I sprayed that lemon straight into my eye though... dang, that was like amateur hour.
author: Rob W.

description:
I order #11 Beef Stew Noodles all the time. The beef is tender and juicy! I can't get enough of it!

My mother had the Five Spice Chicken but it was a bit on the dry side for her.

The Imperial roll is good too!
author: Peter L.

description: The pho here is my go to place in the city...so far.  Its the closest to an authentic broth but I am still on the search for the best broth.
author: LIVE to E.

description:
This is the one of 3 the pho places in Chinatown and none of 'em are very good, especially Golden King.  I've been here a few times to give them a benefit of a doubt that I just didn't catch the good soup stock day but after 3 visits, I still haven't had a bowl of tasty pho.  Their soup obviously taste watered down.  The meat is not very tender and I also had the tendon today and it had a slightly funny taste.

As for the service, I never expect too much from these pho joints but today was the worst.  I know they are busy but today I ate by myself and they seated me in small table.  Then more customers came in, instead of asking them or me if we mind sharing a table, they just seated another party at my table.  I should've just gotten up and left but figured I ordered already.  Should've still left as the pho wasn't that great.  

For good pho, just have to go to Irving Street, either Kevin's Noodle House or PPQ AND they have better service.
author: Cuisine N.

description: It's not the best pho ever but it's cheap and you pay for what you get. AND they also have rice dishes and vermicelli bowls so there's variety. Honestly, I have yet to find a really good pho compared to back home where I'm from in VA but this place is cheap and good for the price.
author: David C.

description:
The Golden King is one of the places I like to meet my boyfriend for lunch during work...really quick, good food, good tea...the service is super fast and pretty good.  If you want to branch out, they have a hard time explaining the menu and the flies grossed me out...

Delicious food though and obviously great prices.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Ordered the rare beef with tripe (my regular). I always try the pho because it's all about the broth. If the broth isn't any good then what's the point of eating pho. This place is always packed and a line out the door during lunch. I always have great service... fast and quick... Price point is GREAT!!! and the ice coffee is very good. It gives you a zing!!! And oh boy do you need it if you are tired. This place is good!!!
author: Valerie A.

description:
A true whole in the wall with added flavors for the senses to boot. If you are the type who refuses to share a table then be prepared to wait. 

I had to be back in the office by 1 PM when my colleague and I chanced upon this place a little after 12:15 PM. We waited less than 5 minutes when they asked if we wanted to share a table. Hell yeah was our collective answer. 

We ordered the pho and it was not only large in portion but tasty as well. I usually put a crap load of plum sauce as I only used sirracha. I'd come back if my normal joint is full. Oh yeah, I made it back in time for my meeting with time to spare.
author: S L.

description: good pho, my fave is the dry rice noddle with beef and egg roll, i think its number 48 or 78. It always yummy to the tummy, my church folks are regulars, but since i haven't been to church... i haven't been a regular. =(
author: Monika T.

description: Very much a fan and a great alternative to Golden Star. I love me some Golden Star, but it often gets very crowded at lunch and you are rushed to eat quickly for high table turn-around. Which is fine! But Golden King's pho is delicious, clean tasting with rich meaty flavor. I had the beef and tendon pho; the tendon was cooked to perfection, my personal sign that this is a great noodle soup joint. Fairly empty when we went in, but filled up a bit. Never was at capacity which was refreshing. Nice to feel that you can chat with friends and take your time enjoying a well-cooked meal. A lot of complaints about atmosphere, but that's not what I'm looking for when I eat pho in the FiDi/Chinatown. I want well-made, authentic food that does not take a long time to prepare and can accomodate small groups. Golden King fits that bill
author: Pim R.

description: Solid food, good flavors, not as good as the one across the street, but a useful alternative when that one is full.  I had the pork, imperial roll and rice plate, which had nice savory flavors with decent quality meat, but the cha gio were not that good.
author: Andy G.

description:
Come here! Friendly service, and I am always served ASAP when I enter the restaurant. They have huge portions, and are very accommodating, especially when I bring big groups of friends.

SF Is constantly foggy and freezing, and this restaurant really delivers the warm, steamy pho that I need to satiate my stomach. 

Lovely restaurant~! Btw, if you see two viet restaurants around the same area, be sure to COME HERE!!
author: harriet h.

description: i come here all the time with my friends and family. the service is pretty good, it comes out quick and delicious! i usuaully get the imperial rolls or the meatball pho, i think this place has like the best imperial rolls out of everywhere else i have tried, yummy!
author: Bailey L.

description:
Ah, sweet serendipity.  I trotted into Golden King after discovering that the Vietnamese restaurant with which I am familiar was full, full, full and I didn't want to wait, wait, wait on my lunch "hour" after trekking from my hulking office in SOMA to China town.

Aside from being unceremoniously shoved into a corner of the restaurant and placed at a table with a couple that looked less than thrilled to have us join them, I enjoyed my lunch today at the Golden King.  I don't expect fancy dcor or bend-over-backwards service at pho-oriented Vietnamese restaurants.  It was inexpensive, seemingly clean, and tasty.  I ate pho, and thought everything was delicious except I prefer lime rather than lemon wedges to garnish my soup, and that sorry lil' lemon wedge had certainly seen better days and was brandishing a wee brown bruise of rot.  I'm kind of a stickler about that.  I also thought the crisp little imperial rolls were yummy, though my partner was less than thrilled with them (never mind him, he's just a stick in the mud anyway); he didn't like that in addition to the meat the roll contained not only fungus but vermicelli.  I thought they were luscious and thoroughly enjoyable little crispy critters.

I want to go back so I can try the spicy shrimp rice, or the lemon chicken shrimp rice, or the shrimp this, or the shrimp that . . . CHRIMPY!

Also, I don't think they serve alcohol here (like every other pho house, except one, that I've ever been in).  So don't go looking for a beer to slake your thirst when chowing on a bun.
author: Chalk A.

description: This is NOT  a sister establishment to Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant, my favorite pho place in Chinatown.  They just copied the name and menu because Golden Star rocks and I guess everyone wants to be Golden.   If you walk around Chinatown, you can also find Golden Sports, Golden this Golden that.....
author: Wakako U.

description:
Only eat #2 Pho ($6.5). The #2 is #1 without beef balls and 50¢ cheaper. The amounts of meat and noodle are just enough for me. The broth is light, not heavy with lots of MSG like other Vietnamese restaurants. I always come here when I crave for a bowl of Pho. I never have to wait for a table since I never come here during lunch time, and the food come out in less than 5 minutes. 

There are few things I don't like about this place.

1) This place can be LOUD! The owner's kids, especially that little boy, are always screening, and the parents would then yell at them. 

2) I enjoy drinking Vietnamese iced coffee. Yet, I will never drink it here. I once made a mistake of ordering coffee here. Their coffee is so watery that you can not taste any coffee.  How can you sell this sh*t?

Tip: Cash only. There are many banks in Chinatown. BOFA and Citibank one and half block away on Grant Ave.
author: Ed W.

description:
This place is clean and their pho is pretty good.  Not too much MSG cause it doesn't make me super thristy and my mouth all sticky/watery like some places.

Only complaint is that it's SUPER slow at night and they have 3-4 wait staffs.  It feels a bit uncomfortable to have 3 people staring at you while you try to eat and any slight movement you make, they come rushing over.
author: Kate L.

description: Very good rice place for $5. The meat is really good and their thai tea is quite good also. My friend told me that the kitchen workers which are Latino understand Chinese. I was quite shocked! The kitchen is downstairs so the workers have to carry the food up one flight of stairs. The restaurant is quite big..
author: Janet Z.

description:
this place is a bit further out from work than i normally venture for lunch but since it was a nice day and we had a taste for pho soup, we went for it.  actually we tried to get into sai's which is closer to us but since sai was packed with a 20 minute wait, it was a no-go.  however, by then we still had our hearts set on noodle soup so i had a good memory of this spot and it was only another few minutes walk so off we went.  

this place is a little bit bigger than some of the other lunch spots near by so it was easier to get a table without a long wait.  the seating and order taking is pretty efficient.  particularly novel i thought was writing down your order # on your paper placemat so that the person delivering the food gets the right food to the right person every time.  that's good.  food is cheap and the noodle soup (pho) is great!  tea is tea (i.e. pretty good). tables are clean and everything was pretty much up to snuff.  

our table-mate ordered the chicken salad.  even though she likes soup, she decided on the salad.  i did warn her that the chicken salad at a chinatown vietnamese restaurant was probably not the chicken salad you're used to from Royal Exchange or something.  i was right and she didn't particularly like nor did she finish her chicken salad.  she said it was "too sweet" whatever that means.  i guess it's a too-sweet sauce.  so my recommendation: stick to the rice and noodle-soup dishes.  cheap and very good.
author: dan h.

description: Come here for lunch once in a while. Fast service, cheap, good food. I usually get their #1 combination pho or the beef vermicelli bun. Can get a little crowded during lunch time with the chinatown/fidi people at times, but usually doesn't take that long for a table.
author: Linda C.

description:
pork chops + imperial rolls = one happy laura. i give it 3.5

went with a coworker this past monday. they were grilled, a bit different than i've had at golden flower but still good.

cash only!
author: laura f.

description: I love the pho here. Their service isn't too bad. They are pretty nice. They would get you whatever you ordered. Most of the time, the serve is good. Occasionally if you get that one lady, she had an attitude. I always come here to eat pho. I think it is the best place to eat at.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Ate lunch. I had the #20 Rib Eye and Chicken Pho. I suspect they use either 5 star spice or some form of the ingredients in their broth, maybe anise. The chicken pieces were a little tough.  Anyhow, I couldn't stop eating it.
author: Mitch L.

description: My all time favorite cheap Vietnamese food.  The #1 beef noodle soup is to die for. I usually get extra tendon because they cook them perfectly - gelatinous and perfectly chewy.  The beef stew noodle soup is good too but I found it to be a little too salty at times.  The Five Spice Chicken Noodle Soup is another classic.  Go here...you won't be dissapointed!!! Total bill is usually $13 for two people.
author: Mia B.

description: This is my favorite vietnamese restaurant!!!  Very affordable, and the beef stew is extremely good!!!
author: Philip L.

description: If you want cheap, fast & tasty Vietnamese food then come to Golden King ! My favorite dish is Grilled Pork Chop Rice Plate . YUM The pork is actually in steak form, not just pieces of pork that's grilled . The Pho is pretty good here . The soup is savory and the noodles are always perfect . They have an option where you can get pho noodles and the pork chop . YUMMY ! Their 5 spiced chicken is good too . VERY VERY tasty .
author: Jenny Y.

description: Every once in awhile, I would walk all the way here for pho (and I work off of Embarcadero). So far, I've never left disappointed. I stopped going to Golden Star, which is across the street. This place is more affordable and the quality is just as good. The portions are just right. I always order a small bowl, and that stuffs me. This restaurant is pretty big, and I've never waited more than a few minutes for a table. Best of all, you get your own table!!! No sharing tables and elbowing strangers! That's a feat in Chinatown. The best part is the 15 minute walk back to the office because it helps me digest.
author: Wendy L.

description:
golden king, where pho is king.  
here's the thing, mad flavor they bring.

you want a cheap meal, huh?
well i say "what the pho?"
or just "wtp?" (it's short 'n easy like me)

me likey cheap noodles, me love 'em long time.
get served here in less time, than it took for this rhyme.
author: James L.

description: Excellent taste. Large bowl. Very economical. Clean environment. The only downside is that they do not endorse the parking. The $7/bowl more than made up for it.
author: Somnath M.

description: I have been to this place several times and as I remembered the previous times, it had always been good. But, for some reasons, maybe because of the recession.. they have been limiting on the food they serve including the  noodle.. #1.. It used to be really good with plenty of meat. The soup has also been decreasing in quality.. it wasn't so tasty anymore and the price has also been raised. Anyway, I was kind of disappointed although the service was fast and friendly.
author: Daisy S.

description: Grabbed some food from here last night to go.  Half way through my salad I found a quarter sized sharp bone.  Luckily I didn't cut up my mouth/throat with it.  Anyway, watch out.
author: Chris F.

description: This place is pretty convenient haha. They give pretty good sizes. Although one time, I did find a fly in my drink but which place wouldn't?
author: Vivian L.

description:
I come here all the freaking time when my friends are in CT, and I am absolutely in love with this place! My friend's relative owns the place, so it's nice to know who's making my food. 

The pho is always good, no matter which one you get. The vermicelli, which I normally dislike, was also surprisingly good, even if I don't like the sauce that comes with it. The tea was good, and the service is wonderful.

Great meal, good prices, and the place looks nice. This is about as good as a pho restaurant can get! I always leave so freaking full. And I love that it's close to downtown and it's smackdab in the center of Chinatown. Just awesome.
author: Peyton L.

description:
it's ok.  

their lemon grass chicken vermicelli with imperial rolls are good.  

their pho is ok.  sometimes the noodles are soggy and the meat stringy, fatty and/or chewy.  for pho, i'd rather go across the street to golden star, even if there's a line there.  

their summer rolls are hit or miss.  sometimes they're super yummy, packed with deliciousness; sometimes, the rice paper is dried out and gross.
author: Reina M.

description: This is the about the only vietnamese restaurant my friend and I will eat at in Chinatown. Their pho is really good...the portions can be large, but I guess that would depend on how hungry you are. I've tried their rice combos and the vermicelli noodles...haven't been disappointed so far. It's cheap, it's good and I'm still happily full from my lunch there.
author: Dolores L.

description: I love this place! It never fails me on a super cold day like today...
author: J T.

description: We came here one day when Golden Flower was closed and thought that this place would probably be almost the same. WRONG total opposite. I ordered a large pho, and they gave me what seemed to be an endless bowl. Okay, but then the pho wasn't that good either. Service was rather bad. The waitress kept coming back and bothering us, and she also got her co-workers to do the same. They assumed that since we were teenagers, we didn't have any money. They also assumed that we were gonna run out the second we were done. Big mistake there. Well I found the service here to be the WORST. But two stars only because their pho was okayy. The prices were cheap, but hey service matters a lot to me. I don't think I'm ever going to come back here unless it's the only place open.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This is the best Pho I've ever had. Even better than their delicious neighbor Golden Star (in my opinion - my girlfriend prefers Golden Star). Their soup for #1 on the menu is really flavorful (of course, with msg) and  it comes in a pretty big portion. My only complaints are that they only take cash and their wait-staff is very asian (you have to wave your arms if you want extra water etc. - but its in chinatown, so what can you expect?)

Love this place though! their vermicelli noodles are really good too!
author: Wade L.

description: I spent most of my high school days here, especially after practices. Craving Vietnamese food in Chinatown? Want something really filling for under $10? Go to Golden King. They have the one of the best Vietnamese food you could get in Chinatown (Golden Flower is the other place in CT; they're both connected somehow). I usually order their #43 vermicelli & pork dish or #1 pho house special. I've also had their yellow curry, porkchop &rice dish; they're all delicious. Serving size is pretty good for what you pay for. However, their prices have increased since I've first started coming here. The wait time for your food is pretty fast & service is alright for an Asian restaurant. This place gets packed around lunchtime, but I usually come here in the mid-/late-afternoons when they're slower. It's also pretty spacious & a bit less busy compared to Golden Flower. Don't forget to have cash in hand; they're cash only!
author: BrendaJoy G.

description: good pho, but I'm always hungry a few hours later
author: William C.

description: Beef stew rice noodles is delicious! The spring rolls are yummy. My co-workers love their pho noodles. I'm not a big fan of the skinny noodles, I think they smell like feet, but with rice noodles, it's pretty good. Great place for a yummy, hot, cheap lunch.
author: ann t.

description:
I usually come here with my friend once a week for lunch right before the rush at lunch.  Since I don't like ordering Pho all the time, i usually go for the rice plates and they are pretty good.  Curry beef or curry chicken or some other rice plate, and vermicelli w egg roll and pork are good and it fills me up.  Prices are cool with me since its usually almost the same prices elsewhere.

Service it alright, sometimes i don't like sharing tables with others. But with a 1 hour lunch break, i don't want to waste time waiting.  But if you don't wanna share and there are no tables open, you gonna have to wait a little bit, but shouldn't be a long wait because they usually try to rush you to finish by giving you your check even though your technically not done yet.  

If your working in the financial district, parking is not a problem since you guys walk.  But, for me coming from outside Chinatown, if you get lucky there s some meters open but .25 for 6 minutes is not really that great, so sometimes parking at the garage right across from the restaurant is the way to go, just be done before an hour so you just pay $2.50 for parking.
author: Jason C.

description: I usually come here once a week to get pho. It's not the best pho but I prefer it over Golden Star. Golden Star's pho is a hit or miss. Meaning, sometimes the broth is good, sometimes not. My co-workers and I enjoy a relaxed setting while conversating over the table. The waitress/waiters does come bother you from time to time as they don't speak english very well. They are definitely chinese and not vietnamese! I've also tried their noodle dishes and thought it was good. Again, it's not the best but I'm not complaining.
author: Johnson H.

description: golden king & golden star is run by the same family. even though they are right across the street from each other, i've never tried out golden star. but other than that, golden king is the best pho place in chinatown! their #1 is the bomb! i always get the rare beef on the side, but sometimes they would charge it extra. the workers are really nice even though they can sometimes forget to get you your drinks & you need to remind them of your drinks again. overall, the pho here is amazing!(:
author: Yummy T.

description:
It seems like I always manage to arrive right when it's the little boy's playtime (8PMish). I say if I can make it through the screaming toddler's random bursts of energy, GK has pretty good food. 

The staff recognize my boyfriend and me because we come here whenever we feel cold and need a bowl of pho, and that's almost everyday in SF. They know I only like lemon in my pho so they don't bother bringing much of anything else.

I order #10 Beef w/ tripe and #43 Pork and imperial roll vermicelli a lot. The three color drink is pretty good if you don't try to figure out what the drink is made of.

Big portions.
Good food.
Friendly people (if you come often and don't forget to tip).
Good prices.
Toddler with extreme vocals.
author: Suzanna L.

description: i always get the #1 combination pho when i dine at golden king for lunch...  the food is good...  the large bowl is a good size and filling...  the only negative is they charge $6 and some change for an order of gou coun...  it's kind of a rip because for that price you can order 2 orders at other vietnamese restaurants...  h-100...
author: Herb F.

description: like golden star but w/ out the wait!  well not entirely true.  the broth for their pho is a bit more clove-y.  not a bad thing but it's noticeable.  the pho is still quite good as are the vermicelli bowls.  the imperial rolls are pretty good too but i truly miss the imperial rolls at tu lan.  anyways, if you wanna get your golder star on but can't because of the line, walk a half block down and get your king on.
author: Swarup B.

description: This place changes every time I come! Friendlier service today, until their friends/relatives got there (then they were too busy chatting on the other side). The soup was extremely bland today. There was no taste besides from the taste of boiled salt and water. I had to add hoi sin sauce today. And unlike the last time, there were more noodles today and the rare slices of steak to the side were of very good quality. This time the colors did not differ from top to bottom of the plate. I also ordered the rare steak w/ lemon juice and it was good. I've had better though, and the portion wasn't the biggest. However, they were large pieces of steak, unlike some other places that has them chopped/sliced up. My burning question still remains: is this beef the same as the ones in my noodle soup? If so, then I had been misled from the beginning! The price for the lemon juice over steak was only $8.05, which is the cheapest I've seen it so far. But most of the noodles are $7.05, which is more than the average Vietnamese place.
author: Elaine H.

description:
good
- solid, cheap Vietnamese food
- bigger and cleaner/newer than its more well-known sister restaurant Golden Star

bad
- it's good, but nothing special, really -- location is the key
author: Anthony W.

description: 3.5 Stars. I like Golden King - when it gets cold on a crazy foggy July day... nothing but a bowl of pho needed to calm the grumbling stomach. I actually prefer to get the chicken pho w/ beef broth...something about the fried garlic that they add in to enhance the flavor...*YUM!* It's unfortunate that I always go with a group of co-workers, in which we all have complicated requests which confuse the heck out of our waiters/waitresses. *sigh* but alas, we all leave happy so no complaints.
author: Jeannette L.

description: this place is not bad compared to golden flower. i've loved golden flower since i was 3 years old but i found out this place opened not too long ago. the customer service is not bad, if youre asian that is. my mom and my brother loves coming to this place on saturdays and i would come along everyone once in a while. their pho is not the greatest but their rice plates hits the spot. the chicken can be a bit salty sometimes but the pork dishes are really good!
author: Kenny L.

description: this restaurant is good if you want good food, cheap prices, and fast service. The thai tea tastes so authentic unlike some other places. the waitresses can be pretty rude to you sometimes which is a minus.
author: Ally W.

description: I go here because Golden Star is busy and I want my bbq pork. It's okay here. Service is fast, so is the food. But go to Golden Star across the street if you have a choice.
author: bob k.

description: Great Vietnamese spot! I come here with my friends about once a week. Decent prices, but the best part is the flavor of their imperial rolls, chicken and beef. My favorites are #43 and #45  - both are vermicelli bowls with imperial rolls, topped with chicken or beef. Their #1 is good as well.
author: Chris W G.

description: Love this place, great service, great pho (best in Chinatown at least), friendly waiters, and not that pricey. Would recommend anyone to eat here. One of my favorites. I go there like at least twice or 3 times a week.
author: Jon J.
